App now sends a broadcast upon signout which is received by WPActionBarActivity.

WPActionBarActivity calls onSignout() when this broadcast is received, so descendants can do activity-specific cleanup when the user signs out.

NativeReaderActivity relies on this to clear the post fragment when the user signs out (otherwise, the previously displayed posts will continue to show if the user logs back in)
Fixed initLocation() force close by passing fragment root view to method.
More reliable method for detecting when the soft keyboard dismisses.

Fixes #450. Seemed like a simple fix but I ran into a bunch of problems. Here’s a summary of the changes:

* WPImageSpan appeared to be storing the exact same data as the MediaFile class. So I simply added a MediaFile instance to WPImageSpan and removed all of the places in code where the WPImageSpan data was copied over to the MediaFile.
* Changed saveMediaFile() in wpDB to also update the media file db row if it already exists.
* Fixed some naming conventions.
* Changed WPImageSpan thumbnail to be larger in the post editor. Looks nice!
* If a WPImageSpan is in the post editor, it will have an edit icon drawn in the lower-right corner to clue in the user that they can tap it to edit the image’s options.
* Removed some duplicated code related to creating image thumbnails.

Merge pull request #523 from wordpress-mobile/issue/363-commenting-over-simplified

Issue/363 commenting over simplified

I couldn’t reproduce #530, but I think some of these changes should help:

* Removed the blog object from the post model, instead just use post.getBlogID to build the blog object when we need it.
* Ensure we have a valid blog object in PostUploadService before attempting to upload the post.
* use notNullStr() on getMaxImageWidth() in the blog model.

I also noticed that we were unnecessarily storing an ID to remember the spinner selection for the max image width. We can just use the Adapter’s getPosition() for that so I deprecated it.
Don’t update the original post if the user chose to discard a brand new post. Also improved the readability of the WordPressDB.deletePost() method.
